conclusion: Consider the forces acting on the charged particle and use the given conditions to derive the velocity.
The charged particle experiences a magnetic force \( F_B = qvB \), perpendicular to both the velocity and the magnetic field.
In the electric field between metal plates MN and PQ, the particle experiences an electric force \( F_E = qE \).
Since the particle moves in a straight line within the electric and magnetic fields, the forces must balance: \( qvB = qE \), leading to \( vB = E \).
When the particle enters the magnetic field, it performs a uniform circular motion due to the magnetic force.
The radius \( R \) of the circular path can be found using the centripetal force equation: \( qvB =  rac{mv^2}{R} \), leading to \( R =  rac{mv}{qB} \).
The particle just fails to exit the magnetic field from side cd, implying the particle's path is tangent to side cd.
The square region has side length \( 2L \), and the plates are of length \( L \). The distance from point S to the boundary of the square (side cd) is \( 2L \).
The radius \( R \) of the circular path should be equal to the distance from S to the boundary: \( R = 2L \).
Using Equation (2): \( 2L =  rac{mv}{qB} \), solving for \( v \) gives \( v =  rac{2qBL}{m} \).
The magnitude of the velocity of the particle when it is shot into point S is \( v =  rac{2qBL}{m} \).
